front.title: Proof of Process Protocol: State Machine, Semantic Events, and Cryptographic Parameters

abstract.t: This document defines the Proof of Process (PoP) protocol for digital authorship attestation. It specifies the evidence collection state machine, semantic event definitions, cryptographic parameters, and Verifiable Delay Function (VDF) mechanisms that bind behavioral evidence to elapsed wall-clock time. The protocol builds on the IETF RATS architecture (RFC 9334) and defines the Attester, Verifier, and Relying Party roles for process-based attestation.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: The proliferation of AI-generated content has created an urgent need for mechanisms that can attest to the human authorship process of digital works. This document specifies the Proof of Process (PoP) protocol, which captures tamper-evident behavioral evidence during content creation and binds it to cryptographic time proofs.
This document is the protocol specification. A companion document, draft-condrey-rats-pop-appraisal, defines the verification procedures, forensic assessment mechanisms, and forgery cost analysis.

section.title: Conventions and Definitions
section.t: The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "NOT RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in BCP 14 when, and only when, they appear in all capitals, as shown here.

section.title: System Model
section.t: The Proof of Process protocol maps onto the RATS architecture defined in . The following entity roles are defined:

section.title: Attester
section.t: The Attester is the software component running on the author's device that collects behavioral evidence during content creation. It operates the evidence collection state machine, computes cryptographic seals, and produces evidence packets. The Attester corresponds to the RATS Attester role.

section.title: Verifier
section.t: The Verifier receives evidence chains and produces Attestation Results. It implements the appraisal algorithms defined in the companion document. The Verifier MUST be operated independently of the Attester to prevent self-attestation.

section.title: Relying Party
section.t: The Relying Party consumes Attestation Results to make trust decisions about content provenance. Examples include publishers, academic institutions, and content platforms.

section.title: Endorser
section.t: An Endorser provides supplementary attestations about the Attester's environment, such as hardware attestation certificates from platform vendors (e.g., TPM manufacturer certificates per ).

section.title: RATS Compatibility
section.t: The protocol supports both the passport model (Attester sends evidence to Verifier, which produces result for Relying Party) and the background-check model (Relying Party forwards evidence to Verifier) as defined in .

section.title: Threat Model
section.t: The following attack taxonomy identifies the threats that the Proof of Process protocol is designed to resist:

section.title: Retype Attack
section.t: An adversary manually retypes AI-generated content to produce fresh behavioral evidence. Defense: the protocol captures fine-grained revision patterns (editing, restructuring, pausing to think) that differ significantly from sequential retyping. The forensic assessment in the companion document detects the characteristic monotonic typing pattern of retyping.

section.title: Replay Attack
section.t: An adversary captures evidence from a legitimate authorship session and attempts to reuse it for different content. Defense: each evidence packet includes a content-hash binding to the specific document state, and session nonces prevent cross-session replay.

section.title: Relay Attack
section.t: An adversary relays evidence from one authorship session to claim credit for a different document. Defense: the content-hash chain binds evidence to specific content transitions, making relay detectable.

section.title: SWF Acceleration
section.t: An adversary uses specialized hardware (FPGAs, ASICs) to accelerate VDF computation, enabling faster-than-real-time evidence generation. Defense: the difficulty parameter is calibrated per-device, and hardware attestation at T3/T4 tiers binds computation to the enrolled device.

section.title: Attestation Environment Spoofing
section.t: An adversary spoofs the hardware attestation environment to bypass device identity checks. Defense: hardware attestation certificates are validated against manufacturer root certificates per .

section.title: Evidence Diversion
section.t: An adversary redirects a legitimate evidence chain to claim authorship of different content by modifying the final content binding. Defense: the content-hash is included in every evidence packet (not just the final one), creating an incremental binding that cannot be diverted post-hoc.

section.title: Security Goals
section.t: The protocol aims to achieve the following security properties:

list.t: Evidence is bound to wall-clock time through Sequential Work Functions, preventing after-the-fact fabrication.
Evidence captures genuine human behavioral characteristics that are computationally expensive to synthesize.
Evidence is cryptographically bound to specific document content at each observation window.
The Attester cannot deny having produced a signed evidence chain, as the chain is bound to the device identity key.

section.title: Evidence Collection State Machine
section.t: The Attester operates a state machine with the following states:

list.t: No active evidence collection session.
Actively capturing behavioral events within an evidence window.
Computing the jitter seal and VDF proof for the current window.
Linking the sealed packet to the evidence chain.
Session paused. A continuation token is generated.

section.title: Semantic Event Definitions
section.t: The following semantic events drive the state machine:

list.t: A character insertion or deletion. Captured with microsecond-resolution timing.
A multi-character edit operation (cut, paste, undo, find-replace).
An inactivity period exceeding the configured pause threshold (default: 5 seconds).
The evidence collection window has elapsed (default: 30 seconds).
The authorship session is terminated.

section.title: Evidence Content Tiers
section.t: Evidence packets are classified into three tiers of increasing richness and assurance:

list.t: Basic behavioral metrics including typing cadence (mean and variance of inter-keystroke intervals), Shannon entropy of timing distributions, and revision count. Sufficient for T1 assurance.
CORE metrics plus Sequential Work Function time-binding, content-hash chain linking evidence to document state, and continuation tokens for cross-session linkage. Required for T2 assurance.
ENHANCED metrics plus hardware-anchored timing (HAT) from a trusted execution environment, continuous device attestation, and environmental sensor data. Required for T3/T4 assurance.

section.title: Attestation Assurance Levels
section.t: Four assurance levels map evidence strength to established frameworks:

list.t: Software-only attestation with behavioral entropy above minimum threshold. Maps to NIST AAL1 and ISO/IEC 29115 LoA 1.
T1 plus SWF time-binding proof. Maps to NIST AAL2 and ISO LoA 2.
T2 plus hardware-anchored timing from TPM or Secure Enclave. Maps to NIST AAL3 and ISO LoA 3.
T3 plus continuous device attestation and environmental sensing. Exceeds NIST AAL3, maps to ISO LoA 4.

section.title: Profile Architecture
section.t: All implementations MUST support the following mandatory-to-implement features:

list.t: CBOR encoding per
COSE_Sign1 with ES256 per
SHA-256 for content and chain hashing
HMAC-SHA-256 for jitter seals
UUIDv7 session identifiers per
Evidence window duration: 15-60 seconds (default 30)

section.title: Verifiable Delay Function Mechanisms
section.t: The framework employs Verifiable Delay Functions (VDFs) to bind evidence to elapsed wall-clock time:
y = x^(2^t_vdf) mod N
where x is derived from the evidence packet hash, t_vdf controls the time parameter, and N is an RSA modulus from a trusted setup.

section.title: Jitter Seal
section.t: seal = HMAC-SHA-256(device_key, timing_vector || t_vdf || nonce)

section.title: Continuation Tokens
section.t: Continuation tokens link evidence across sessions using HKDF-derived session keys with per-session salt.

section.title: Privacy Considerations
section.t: Evidence packets MUST be constructed using the principle of data minimization per .

section.title: Security Considerations
section.t: See the companion appraisal document for detailed security analysis. Protocol-level security properties include resistance to replay, relay, and retype attacks as described in .

section.title: IANA Considerations
section.t: This document requests registration of the media type application/pop-evidence+cbor and COSE header parameter pop-chain-ref.
